gurmukhi: kihE juiDStir inMsR huie sunIXY sRI biRjrwj ] Xh smwju qumhI kIXo kauqk dyKn kwj ]1598]
transliteration: Raajaa Judhishtar(i) Ninmra Hue Souneeyai Sribrijraaj|| Yah Samaaj(u) Toum-hikeeyo Kaoutak Dekhan Kaaj||1598||
translation: Yudhishtar said with humility, “O Lord of Braja ! all this play has been created by you in order to see the sport.”1598.

gurmukhi: XO niRp hir sy bcn sunwey ] bhuro aun Bt mwr igrwey ] pun mlyC kI sYnw DweI ] nwm iqnhu kib dyq bqweI ]1599]
transliteration: Yaoun Nrip Har(i) Se Bachanndsu Naae|| Bahuro Oun Bhat Maar Giraae|| Poun Malechh Kisainaa Dhaaee|| Naam Tinoh Kabi Det Bataaee||1599||
translation: On this side Yudhishtar said this to Krishna and on that side the king Kharag Singh knocked down a large part of the army; then the poet relates now;1599.

gurmukhi: nwihr Kwn JVwJV KwN blbIr bhwdr Kwn qbY ] pun Kwn inhMg BVMg JVMg lry rn Awgy fry n kbY ]
transliteration: Naahir Khaan Jhadaajhard Khaan Balbeer Bahaadar Khaan Tabai|| Poun Khaan Nihan Bhadan Jhadan Dare Ran Aage Dare Na Kabai||
translation: Nahar Khan, Jharajhar Khan, Bahadur Khan, Nihang Khan, Bharang and Jharang were such expert warriors in warfare that they never had any fear of war;

gurmukhi: ijh rUp inhwr frY idgpwl mhw Bt qy kbhU n dbY ] kir bwn kmwn Dry AiBmwn soN Awie pry qb Kwn sbY ]1600]
transliteration: Jih Roop Nihaar Darai Digpaal Mahaa Bhat Te Kab-hoo Na Dabai|| Kar(i) Baan Kamaan Ddare Abhimaan Son Aae Dare Tab Khaan Sabai||1600||
translation: Seeing whose figures even the protectors of the directions feared, such mighty warriors could never be suppressed by anyone; all those Khans, taking their bows and arrows in their hands came to fight proudly with the king.1600.

gurmukhi: jwhd Kwnhu j`br Kwn su vwhd Kwn gey sMg sUry ] caup chU ids qy aumgy icq mY cpros ky mwr mrUry ]
transliteration: Jaahad Khaanoh Jabbar Khaan Su Vaahad Khaan Gad San Soore|| Chaoup Chahoo Dis Te Oumge Chit Mai Chapros Ke Maar Daroore||
translation: They were accompanied by the warriors like Zahid Khan, Jabbar Khan and Wahid Khan; they rushed forward from all the four directions getting angry;

gurmukhi: gory mlyC cly niRp pY iek sXwh cly iek BUry ] BUp srwsn lY qbhI su AcUr bfy iCn BIqr cUry ]1601]
transliteration: Gore Malechh Chale Nrip Pai Ik Syaah Chale Ik Bhoore|| Bhoop Saraasan Lai Tab-hisu Achr Bade Chhin Bheetar Choore||1601||
translation: The malechhas of all colours, white, black, grey etc., marched forward to fight with the king; at that very instant, the king, taking his bow in his hand, pulversied all these angry warriors.1601.

gurmukhi: kop mlyCn kI pRqnw su duDw kir kY siq Dw kir fwrI ] bIr pry khUM bwj mry khUM JUm igry gij BU pir BwrI ]
transliteration: Kop Malechhan Kipratnaa Ssu Dudhaa Kar(i) Kai Sat(i) Dhaa Kar(i) Ddaree|| Beer Dare Kahoon Baaj Dare Kahoon Jhoom Gire Gad(i) Bhoo Par(i) Bhdaree||
translation: The king, in ire, dividing the army of malechhas into two parts, broke them up further; somewhere the warriors, somewhere the horses powerful huge elephants lay dead;

gurmukhi: GUmiq hY khUM Gwie lgy Bt bol skYN n gey blu hwrI ] Awsn lwie mno mn rwie lgwvq iDAwn bfy bRqDwrI ]1602]
transliteration: Ghoomat(i) Hai Kahoon Ghaae Lage Bhat Bol Sakain Na Gad Bal(u) Hdaree|| Oosan Laae Mano Man Raae Lagadvat Dhiaan Bade Bratdhdaree||1602||
translation: The elephants had fallen after swinging; some of the wouded warriors are writhing and some have lost the power of speech; some are sitting silently like some fasting hermit in meditation.1602.
